facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 2154 of 1968 before the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 2154 of 1968. Appeal from the judgment and decree dated March

facts.text: Appeal from the judgment and decree dated March 18, 1968 of the Bombay High Court in Appeal No. 102 of 1966.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and decree dated March 18, 1968 of the Bombay High Court in Appeal No. 102 of 1966. Naunit Lal, for the appellant. M. Tarkunde and B. R. Agarwala,

facts.text: The respondent filed the suit against the appellant Municipality for recovery of Rs. 1,00,012/- as damages to respondent's property due to flood caused by gross negligence of appellant.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent filed the suit against the appellant Municipality for the recovery of Rs. 1,00,012/- as damages suffered to the respondents property on account of flood caused by acts of gross negligence on the part of the appellant.

facts.text: Bombay High Court passed decree in favour of respondent for Rs. 54,560/- with interest at 6% per annum.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court passed a decree in favour of the respondent for Rs. 54,560/- with interest at 6 per annum.

facts.text: Respondent has a structure abutting on Yacoob Road which is about 12 feet wide.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent has a structure abutting on the Yacoob Road. The width of Yacoob Road is about 12 feet.

facts.text: Open nallah running parallel to Yacoob Road on other side, about 45 feet wide.

anchor.surface_text: On the other side of the road is an open nallah running parallel to the road. The nallah is about 45 feet in width,

facts.text: Nallah provides passage for dirty water and rain water to the creek during November to May.

anchor.surface_text: The nallah provides for passage of dirty water, rain water to the creek during the months of November to May.

facts.text: Government of Maharashtra demolished a portion of Varala Dam in May 1963.

anchor.surface_text: The Government of Maharashtra demolished a portion of Varala Dam in the month of May, 1963.

facts.text: Water stored in the lake was bound to pass through the nallah to the creek after dam demolition.

anchor.surface_text: In companysequence the rater stored in the lake was bound to pass through the nallah to the creek.

facts.text: Appellant commenced work of laying cement slab across the nallah in second week of June 1963.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant companymenced the work of laying cement slab across the nallah in about the second week of June, 1963.

facts.text: Centering work to support the slab continued in position in nallah till first week of July 1963.

anchor.surface_text: The centering work to support and settle the slab companytinued to remain in its position in the nallah till about the first week of July, 1963.

facts.text: Appellant prepared plan for narrowing nallah without provision for additional rain water from Varala lake catchment area.

anchor.surface_text: First, the appellant prepared a plan for narrowing the nallah in front of the respondents shop without making any provision for the passage of additional rain water from the Varala lake catchment area.

facts.text: Centering work, cement slab constituted grave obstruction to rain water passage.

anchor.surface_text: Second, the existence, of the centring work and the cement slab across the nallah companystituted a grave obstruction against the passage of rain water through the nallah.

facts.text: Appellant neglected to keep nallah passage free from construction work and debris.

anchor.surface_text: Third, the appellant neglected and failed to see that the passage of the nallah was kept free and unobstructed by work of companystruction and debris for providing a safe passage of the rain water

facts.text: Heavy rain at Bhiwandi on 5th, 6th and 7th July 1963.

anchor.surface_text: Fourth, in the numbermal companyrse of the monsoon season, there was heavy rain at Bhiwandi on the 5th, 6th and the 7th days of July, 1963.

facts.text: Appellant had knowledge in April 1963 of demolition of Varala Dam above 6 feet above ground level.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court found these facts The appellant had knowledge in the month of April, 1963 of the demolition of the Varala Dam above a height of 6 feet above ground level.

facts.text: Appellant completed laying of slab between Teen Batti bridge and Habsanali bridge after April 1963 with knowledge of dam demolition.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant companypleted the laying of the slab between Teen Batti bridge and Habsanali bridge after April, 1963 with the knowledge of the demolition of the Varala Dam.

facts.text: Appellant narrowed water-way near Teen Batti bridge insufficient for discharge from increased catchment area due to demolition.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant narrowed the water-way near Teen Batti bridge to an extent that it was insufficient for discharge of water from the increased catchment area. because of the demolition.

facts.text: Appellant did not remove centring at Lendi bridge.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant with full knowledge of the companysequences narrowed the water passage, put a slab on it and did number remove the centring at Lendi bridge.

facts.text: Appellant allowed accumulation of garbage and debris obstructing water passage.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant allowed accumulation of garbage and debris so as to obstruct the passage of water.

facts.text: Heavy rain on 4th, 5th and 6th July 1963 caused water accumulation at southern end of Habsanali bridge, flooding surrounding area including respondent's factory to 2 feet deep for 3 days.

anchor.surface_text: Because of heavy rain on the 4th, 5th and 6th days of July, 1963 was accumulated at the southern end of Habsanali bridge and entered the surrounding area. Water was two feet deep in the factory of the respondent. This state of affairs companytinued for three days.

facts.text: Portion of nallah between Habsanali bridge and Lendi bridge covered with concrete slab in 1963.

anchor.surface_text: The portion of the nallah which lies between Habsanali bridge and Lendi bridge was companyered with companycrete slab in 1963.

facts.text: Nallah runs from south to north, flows to creek at northern end, five bridges over it.

anchor.surface_text: The further findings are these. The nallah runs from south to numberth. The water carried by it flows on to the creek at the numberthern end of the nallah. There are five bridges over the nallah.

facts.text: Supreme Court holds Municipality acted recklessly, aware of possible harm but did nothing, hence mala fide, not protected by Section 167 of Bombay District Municipal Act.

anchor.surface_text: In the facts of this case we hold that the defendant was aware of possible harm and yet cared to do numberhing about it. The action was, therefore, reckless, and therefore in the eye of law mala fide, and there fore unprotected by section 167 of the Act.
Section 167 of the Bombay District Municipal, Act companyfers protection on the Municipality in respect of anything in good faith done or intended to be done.

arguments.claim: Section 167 of the Bombay District Municipal Act confers protection on the Municipality in respect of anything in good faith done or intended to be done.

anchor.surface_text: Section 167 of the Bombay District Municipal, Act confers protection on the Municipality in respect of anything in good faith done or intended to be done.

arguments.claim: The expression done in good faith means done honestly, whether done negligently or not.

anchor.surface_text: The expression done in good faith has been defined in the Bombay General Clauses Act, 1904 and in the General Clauses Act, to mean, done honestly, whether done negligently or not.

arguments.claim: Being aware of possible harm to others, and acting in spite thereof, is acting with reckless disregard of consequences.

anchor.surface_text: Being aware of possible harm to others, and acting in spite thereof, is acting with reckless disregard of consequences.

arguments.claim: Reckless disregard of consequences and mala fides stand equal where the actual state of mind of the actor is relevant.

anchor.surface_text: Reckless disregard of consequences and mala fides stand-equal, where the actual- state of mind of the actor is relevant.

arguments.claim: Negligence does not necessarily mean mala fides; something more than negligence is necessary.

anchor.surface_text: The Bombay, as also, the Central, General Clauses Acts, help only in so far as they lay down that negligence does not necessarily mean mala fides. Something more than negligence is necessary.

arguments.claim: The defendant was aware of possible harm and yet cared to do nothing about it; the action was reckless and therefore in the eye of law mala fide, unprotected by section 167.

anchor.surface_text: In the facts of this case we hold that the defendant was aware of possible harm and yet cared to do nothing about it. The action was, therefore, reckless, and therefore in the eye of law mala fide, and there fore unprotected by section 167 of the Act.

holdings.text: In the facts of this case we hold that the defendant was aware of possible harm and yet cared to do nothing about it. The action was, therefore, reckless, and therefore in the eye of law mala fide, and therefore unprotected by section 167 of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: In the facts of this case we hold that the defendant was aware of possible harm and yet cared to do nothing about it. The action was, therefore, reckless, and therefore in the eye of law mala fide, and there fore unprotected by section 167 of the Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Court accepted High Court findings on Municipality's knowledge of dam demolition, narrowing of nallah without adequate provision, retention of centering, accumulation of debris; applied to conclude subjective awareness of harm without mitigation distinguishes from objective negligence.

holdings.text: Being aware of possible harm to others, and acting in spite thereof, is acting with reckless disregard of consequences.

anchor.surface_text: Being aware of possible harm to others, and acting in spite thereof, is acting with reckless disregard of consequences.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Court distinguished recklessness (actual awareness of harm acted upon) from negligence (presumed foresight via reasonable man test).

holdings.text: Reckless disregard of consequences and mala fides stand equal, where the actual state of mind of the actor is relevant. This is so in the eye of law, even if there might be variations in the degree of moral reproach deserved by recklessness and mala fides.

anchor.surface_text: Reckless disregard of consequences and mala fides stand-equal, where the actual- state of mind of the actor is relevant. This is so in the eye of law,  1  2 A. C. 616. even if there might be variations in the degree of moral reproach

holdings.reasoning_summary: Where actual state of mind matters (as in good faith clauses), recklessness equates to bad faith legally, citing Jones v. Gordon.

holdings.text: negligence does not necessarily mean mala fides. Something more than negligence is necessary.

anchor.surface_text: The Bombay, as also, the Central, General Clauses Acts, help only in so far as they lay down that negligence does not necessarily mean mala fides. Something more than negligence is necessary.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Statutory definitions of good faith explicitly include negligent acts if honest; requires proof beyond negligence like recklessness.

anchor.surface_text: In Jones v. Gordon 1  Lord Blackburn pointed out the distinction between the case of a person who was honestly blundering and careless, and the case of a person who has acted number honestly. An authority is number acting honestly where an authority has a suspicion, that there is something wrong and does number make further enquiries. Being aware of possible harm to others, and acting in spite thereof, is acting with reckless disregard of companysequences.

precedents.cited_proposition: Distinction between honestly blundering and careless conduct on one hand, and acting not honestly on the other; an authority not acting honestly if it has suspicion of something wrong but does not inquire further; being aware of possible harm and acting despite it amounts to reckless disregard of consequences equivalent to mala fides
